"Idiomatic" programming is when we use the idioms of the language community rather than the literal or obvious choices.
But it actually tests whether `foo` is `null` or `undefined`. It is an idiom rather than cryptic, if the community standardizes on its use.
For example, in JavaScript, testing `foo == null` is an idiom. Its obvious or "literal" meaning is to test whether `foo` is `null`.
But the community has a shared understanding of its actual behaviour, so it is considered acceptable and not cryptic.
A programming idiom does something that is not "obvious" from first principles or according to the language's general style.
An "idiom" is a construct thats figurative meaning differs from its literal meaning.
